div.p: RBG Kew, Kew Correspondence, Australia, Mueller, 1882-90, f. 105.

12/6/84
There is a tick in purple pencil to the left of the date.

It needs not my assurance, dear Sir Joseph, that I will do all in my power for poor Renner, when he arrives here, and if you have any means of communicating with the Crown-Princess of Prussia, I beg of you to assure H.R.H., that I felt honored with the confidence placed in me, to interest myself in HRH’s Protegée. I had some months ago a letter from Herr Renner, in which he alluded to the interest, shown so condescendingly and feelingly to him by the Crown-Princess.
Princess Victoria Adelaide, eldest daughter of Queen Victoria and wife of Crown Prince Friedrich of Prussia. Renner's letter not found. To this letter I replied at once, giving him at the same time some little insight before hands into Australian affairs.
Letter not found. I will see, that he is not placed in a position, that would not be congenial to him, and would not be adapted to his constitution and frailness.
M wrote to the Chief Secretary, G. Berry, on 20 August 1884, seeking Gerhard Renner’s appointment as a Junior Assistant in his department. The appointment was approved; see T. Wilson to M, 26 August 1884. See also M to T. Wilson, 27 August 1884, and M to J. Hooker, 8 September 1884.

The more cheering accounts from Mr Bentham through you
See J. Hooker to M, 14 March 1884. leads me to hope, that he gradually will gain some strength, and thus be spared us for many a year as a friend, though we cannot reckon perhaps on renewed labors of his any more.

I regret to hear of Mrs Dyers
Hooker's daughter Harriet, who was married to William Thiselton-Dyer. indisposition, but feel sure under your counsels she will recover her strength, when the summer has set in as by this time is the case.

The winter is here now much against me, and my cough has become so aggravated, that I shall not likely be able to leave my sickroom, til the vernal warmth will recommence in September. Til August we have here night-frosts.
it is cheering to see you preserve your health so well, so that your marvellous mass of labors can proceed uninterruptedly.

div.p:
12/6/84
What is presented here as a postscript is on a separate sheet, filed immediately after the sheet containing the letter. It has no addressee. However, its position in the file, together with its having the same date as the letter, suggests that M sent it as an enclosure with his letter to Hooker. It is annotated in Joseph Hooker’s hand, 'And Aug 17/84' [letter not found], and in William Watson’s hand, 'Seeds Recd. & Sown 30-7-84 | W.W.'.
